newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - May 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - May 23.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories on Friday:
* The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 32.56 points.
* Apple Computer Inc has decided to spin off the division that produces Newton handheld computers.
* The Securities and Exchange Commission is putting forth ideas for revising the way it regulates stock markets to try to keep pace with modern changes.
* Oppenheimer & Co has moved around its top executives and has put together an operating committee to try to cultivate a new generation of executives.
* Institutional shareholders of Digital Equipment Corp plan to get together to discuss ways to increase the company's stock price.
* Federal Reserve policy makers were unanimous in raising the overnight bank lending rate on March 25.
* The dollar rose sharply against the yen and fell against the mark.
* Negotiators in the tobacco settlement talks have taken steps toward a resolution on certain regulatory and legal issues, but considerable hurdles remain.

* A doctor who received a patent for noticing the relationship in tests of pregnant women between levels of a hormone and the incidence of Down Syndrome has stirred a dispute by demanding royalties based on the finding.
* Bear Stearns Cos Inc, whose trades it processed for the defunct A.R. Baron & Co are being investigated, was among companies that lost records in a fire at a storage center earlier this month.
* President Clinton has decided to postpone an effort to secure fast-track authority to negotiate trade agreements.
* In a reverse of recent trends, Japanese executives are now looking to American companies for management ideas.
* Lazard Freres & Co has named a new deputy chief executive, succeeding Felix Rohatyn, who was named U.S. Ambassador to France.
* Peter Lund, the president of CBS television, a unit of Westinghouse Electric, has resigned after he was informed he would no longer oversee the TV stations division.
* Over the past 18 months, wages at the low-end of the scale have been picking up, rising significantly faster than the inflation rate.
